title: How to Make a Cheerleading Hair Bow

steps.headline: Grab a few different colors of ribbon.
steps.description: If you are using 2 different colors, cut them both to 1 1/2 feet (.45 m) long, but cut two sections of one. If you are using 3 different ribbons, cut them all to be 1 ⁄2 feet (0.5 m) long. Also cut a 3 inch (7.6 cm) piece of any of the ribbons for the middle of your finished hair bow. Don't worry about cutting your ends yet; we'll do that near the end.

steps.headline: Using the glue gun, draw a line on the edge of the first ribbon piece.
steps.description: Do it as fast as possible so it doesn't dry. If you can, have someone else helping you -- four hands work faster than two. You probably don't want to get the glue on your carpet or nice counter top. Set down some newspapers or use a surface you're not worried messing up.

steps.headline: Carefully place the second ribbon piece onto the wet glue.
steps.description: Press down cautiously and wait to dry. Try to get it as straight as possible -- you want each color to be displayed equally. If you have only two colors, be sure to have the odd color out in the middle.

steps.headline: Draw another line of glue on the second ribbon piece.
steps.description: Do it fast! Pin down the ends of the first ribbon if you're worried about it moving.

steps.headline: Carefully place the third ribbon piece onto the wet glue.
steps.description: Be careful while you press down as to not burn yourself. You should now have a tri-toned piece of ribbon, in all your school's colors (or whatever colors you want). Now the ribbon is complete and you can move onto forming the bow!

steps.headline: Fold/form the ribbon into the cancer awareness symbol.
steps.description: Make sure there are no unnecessary twists in the ribbon.

steps.headline: Smush the top loop back and down to form the two ears of the bow.
steps.description: Pinch the middle with your thumb and forefinger and squish it all together. You're not creating an actual tie and bow, it just looks like it.

steps.headline: Now use the twist tie to keep it in place.
steps.description: Don't worry about the extra length of the twist tie; it'll be done away with later.

steps.headline: Squirt a giant glob of glue on the back of the twist tie.
steps.description: This will be used to secure the hair tie to the ribbon piece. Try not to use too much -- you don't want to get yourself gloopy. The technical term!

steps.headline: Put the hair tie into the glue.
steps.description: Hold it there for about 15 seconds. The longer, the better. Hot glue is generally permanent, so don't worry about your ribbon coming off.

steps.headline: Secure the twist tie around the hair tie.
steps.description: Make sure the hair tie is under the ribbon to secure it in place. If the twist tie is still too long, cut off the excess.

steps.headline: Cut a triangle out of the bottom of the tails to keep edges from fraying.
steps.description: Optional: You can remove the twist tie once the glue has dried or keep it there for extra strength. And, if you so choose, you can take that 3 inches (7.6 cm) of ribbon you cut out earlier and glue gun it over the twist tie to obscure it from view.
